DOC.HEAD: DOE Reopens Plutonium Processing Plant For Limited Operations
DOC.TEXT: A key plutonium production plant at the Hanford nuclear reservation reopened Sunday to process spent nuclear fuel that has been stuck in the plant since it was shut down a year ago, the government said. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins authorized the reopening Friday based on a review by the department and the need to improve safety at the facility, said Department of Energy spokesman Tom Bauman. The Plutonium-Uranium Extraction Plant takes nuclear fuel rods from Hanford's N Reactor and dissolves them to extract plutonium and uranium. The plutonium must be processed further at another facility for use in nuclear weapons. The N Reactor has been closed since late 1986, but PUREX continued to operate until last December to reduce a large stockpile of irradiated fuel. Westinghouse Hanford Co., which operates the nuclear production complex for the government, said it shut the plant down because operators did not follow procedures in handling a loss of steam pressure. DOE officials have said previously that the shutdown of the PUREX plant would not hurt the country's ability to make nuclear weapons. A review of safety requirements and procedures, along with retraining of about 500 PUREX workers, was completed in March. Equipment repairs and improvements to waste treatment systems at the 33-year-old plant delayed the resumption of operations, Bauman said. PUREX is expected to remain open for four to six weeks to finish processing material that was in the plant when it was shut down, Bauman said. Then, the plant will be shut for another year to make additional modifications and improvements before resuming the processing of spent fuel in storage at Hanford, Bauman said. Processing that inventory is expected to take until 1995. From PUREX, plutonium is sent to Hanford's Plutonium Finishing Plant, which has been operating only periodically for the past year. Bauman said that plant will gear up eventually to handle the additional plutonium from PUREX, but he could not say when that might occur. The nation's only other plutonium extraction operation is at the Savannah River Plant in South Carolina, but it has little to do because reactors at that site have been closed for safety reasons.
